thread.title: ‘Unacceptable at any level’: Concern over AFLW hits
thread.title_full: ‘Unacceptable at any level’: Concern over AFLW hits

title: ‘Unacceptable at any level’: Concern over AFLW hits
text:
AFLW must clamp down on foul play after ‘unacceptable’ big hits says Tadhg Kennelly  02pm @tommorris32 Source: FOX SPORTS SYDNEY Swans premiership player Tadgh Kennelly believes the league needs to clamp down on foul play in the newly formed AFL Women’s competition. 
Unlike their male counterparts, AFLW players are not professionals, with Kennelly arguing as a result the women don’t have the time to perfect self-protection methods that are common place in the men’s game. 
The issue is in the spotlight following a string of heavy hits on across the first two weeks of the AFLW, headlined by Demon Meg Downie’s sickening concussion. 
Magpie Sophie Casey’s hit on Downie will cost her a big chunk of the AFLW season after the Match Review Panel offered her a two-week suspension . 
“This is uncharted ground and it takes time and a lot of coaching to get used to protecting the head,” Kennelly, who adopted the game after spending his junior years playing Gaelic football, told Fox Sports News 500 . 
“I have a concern — it’s a small concern — but I know how difficult it is coming from the other side of the world and protecting your neck and head. It took me a long time to get over it and get it right. That’s the concern I have with women’s football. Dee KO'd by brutal bump 1:16 
“There are a lot of girls who haven’t played a whole lot of AFL football at the top level and not as fulltime professionals.” 
AFLW has received rave reviews in its first fortnight, leading to coverage that is normally reserved for fully-fledged professional sport. 
However Kennelly cautioned against expectations of grandeur, suggesting a patient approach is required from fans and the media alike. 
“Yes we are going to critique them as if they are fulltime because it’s on TV … But they are not,” he said. 
“The (behind the play) stuff is unacceptable at any level — man, woman or child.” 
Live stream EVERY game of the JLT Community Series on FOX SPORTS. Get your free 2-week FOXTEL PLAY trial and start watching in minutes. SIGN UP NOW > 
Australian female cricketer Alyssa Healy shared Kennelly’s sentiments, but also indicated the recent hard knocks have occurred because women are trying to prove they are as tough as men. 
She urged the female footballers to hit hard, but do so fairly. 
“Most sport is very male dominated,” Healy, who has played 41 one-dayers for the Southern Stars, told Fox Sports News 500. 
“When you go out there you want to prove that you’re just as good as the blokes. Footy is that you want to tackle hard and make that contest. Maybe the girls are going just a little bit too hard and maybe it will even itself out.”
